subclusters.subcluster_name: Lipid Peroxidation and Electrophilic Aldehyde Damage Theory

theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on imbalance between oxidative damage and repair, emphasizing mitochondrial ROS production and genetic variability in antioxidant pathways influencing aging.
Centers on mitochondrial ROS as main source of oxidative damage causing cellular dysfunction and inflammation driving aging.
Highlights free radical damage from mitochondrial ROS and antioxidant enzyme roles in nervous system aging.
Describes ROS accumulation and antioxidant enzyme regulation affecting lifespan, with genetic control in C. elegans.
Focuses on oxidative stress causing aging and lifespan extension via upregulation of antioxidant enzymes regulated by insulin/IGF-1 signaling.
Emphasizes free radical damage causing lipid peroxidation and immune system aging, mitigated by antioxidants.
Focuses on ROS causing molecular damage and the protective role of antioxidant enzymes and thiol oxidoreductases in yeast aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Lipid Peroxidation and Electrophilic Aldehyde Damage Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Highlights oxidative stress initiating lipid peroxidation producing 4-HNE, an electrophilic aldehyde causing protein damage and aging.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Lipid Peroxidation and Electrophilic Aldehyde Damage Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on ROS-induced lipid peroxidation in oocytes producing 4-HNE that disrupts spindle integrity and causes aging-related defects.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Lipid Peroxidation and Electrophilic Aldehyde Damage Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Describes oxidative damage to membranes and the role of lipophilic antioxidants in protecting against lipid peroxidation and aging.
General oxidative stress theory emphasizing ROS/RNS imbalance causing damage to biomolecules and aging, with antioxidant defenses.
Free radical theory focusing on mitochondrial ROS production linked to metabolic rate and sex differences in lifespan.
Focuses on ROS as causal agents and antioxidant enzymes like methionine sulfoxide reductases that repair oxidative damage influencing lifespan.
Similar to T014175, emphasizes oxidative stress causing aging and lifespan extension via antioxidant enzyme upregulation regulated by insulin/IGF-1.
Describes oxidative damage accumulation and modulation by dietary restriction and exercise affecting aging.
Focuses on redox imbalance and oxidative damage as aging causes, with calorie restriction modulating glutathione and thioredoxin antioxidant systems.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: Proteasome Dysfunction and Oxidative Stress Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on oxidative stress causing proteasome dysfunction in T lymphocytes, impairing protein degradation and immune aging.
Describes reduced oxidative damage in long-lived birds as a mechanism for extended lifespan despite high metabolism.
Proposes 8-oxoG oxidative DNA lesion as a hormetic modulator of gene expression and adaptive oxidative stress responses.

theory_assignments.subcluster_name: SKN-1/Nrf2 Antioxidant Signaling and Longevity Theory
theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on SKN-1/Nrf2 transcription factor activation by oxidative stress to induce antioxidant defenses and promote neuroprotection and longevity.
Emphasizes FOXO transcription factors regulating antioxidant genes in response to ROS, modulated by insulin/IGF-1 signaling to affect lifespan.
Describes resveratrol modulating oxidative stress and insulin-like signaling pathways affecting FOXO activity and lifespan.
Focuses on transient mitochondrial ROS signaling activating AMPK and SKN-1/NRF2 pathways inducing adaptive stress responses and longevity.
Describes mild mitochondrial ROS increase via glycolytic inhibition triggering hormetic stress responses that promote lifespan extension.
Focuses on ROS accumulation causing oxidative damage in stem cells leading to dysfunction and aging, with mitochondrial dysfunction as key source.
Focuses on ROS production in neural cells causing oxidative damage and neurodegeneration, linked to mitochondrial dysfunction and enzyme activity.
